Give us a wink and make me think of you

The absurdity of the song comes full circle with this line. People only think of parking enforcement officers when concerned about getting a ticket and fine for violating the rules. Here, the conventions of authority are reversed with the implication that the blissful protagonist’s only concern is violating the parking officer.
When I caught a glimpse of Rita

This line contributes to the somewhat popular conspiracy theory that Paul McCartney died in a car accident and that he was replaced by a look-alike. Some theorists say that because he “caught a glimpse of Rita”, Paul was distracted and crashed. There are many other very evident clues, but this song specifically details the supposed car crash.

Lovely Rita, meter maid
 May I inquire discreetly (Lovely Rita)
 When are you free to take some tea with me? (Lovely Rita maid! Ahh-ah-ah)

McCartney’s rhyme scheme here is seriously dense. “Rita” and “meter” are compound rhymes. Their first syllable rhymes with “discrete”; McCartney draws out the end of that word to emphasise the assonance. There’s then a triple rhyme based on the assonance of the “ee” sound.

Move over, Rakim and Big Daddy Kane – Paul McCartney was spitting like Golden Age rappers in 1967.

In McCartney’s native Britain, the primary villains of middle-class cities are more commonly called parking wardens. “Meter maid” is unheard of. When Paul heard the American phrase, it called to mind archetypal “sexy maids”:

There was a story in the paper about ‘Lovely Rita’, the meter maid. She’s just retired as a traffic warden. The phrase ‘meter maid’ was so American that it appealed, and to me a ‘maid’ was always a little sexy thing: ‘Meter maid. Hey, come and check my meter, baby.’

–Paul McCartney, Anthology

This song is filled with fun sounds and harmonies including various groaning, sighing and screaming noises, cha cha chas, and the playing of the paper and combs.

The paper and combs can best be heard immediately before the line “When it gets dark I tow your heart away”. They collected      paper from Abbey Road’s lavatory. Stamped with the words, “Property of EMI”, the paper is blown on against the comb, giving a kazoo sound.

This is one of the less often covered Beatles songs, Fats Domino does a really good cover though:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NEbDR7KXr7c

Told her I would really like to see her again
 Got the bill and Rita paid it

Meter maids are always given this cold-hearted stereo type, however this one is charming and provided good company for dinner. As soon as the narrator expresses his interest, this meter maid picked up the tab! What a gal!! More like a meter maiden.



Sounds like she’s “Heaven-Cent” (very bad pun)
